column3: Did you or a consultant perform an analysis of cost-effectiveness? If so, please include this information. If not, consider assessing the cost-effectiveness
Your hypothesis lacks clarity. Please revise it to succinctly and clearly communicate your hypothesis

Eliminate all unnecessary claims of priority. Editors dislike overt assertions such as “we were the first” or “for the first time;” through acceptance and publication, the originality and relevance of your research should become apparent
When you first introduce an acronym, write out all of the words and then include the acronym in parentheses. Henceforth, you can use only the acronym
Your description of your study does not directly follow your abstract, please revise to eliminate this inconsistency
Your conclusion does not directly follow your results, please revise to eliminate this inconsistency
Your conclusions are too reliant on certain sub-groups, please expand to include all data and results

In our reading of the manuscript, you appear to overemphasize the positive findings and either downplay or fail to mention the negative findings. In order to ensure objectivity, expand your discussion to more accurately reflect the data. This will not diminish your research in the eyes of the editors or readership, as they prefer papers devoid of bias
The desired format for a summary statement is one sentence--sometimes transcribed from your discussion section--that encapsulates the significance of your study
Journals prefer if you include up to three sentences about the implications of your research on patient care as part of this section. We recommend that you include this in your revised manuscript

column3: The “Advances in Knowledge” and “Implications for Patient Care” offer readers a direct look at the importance of your research. Therefore, please keep them short and specific, strive for clarity, and correlate them with your results
The word “significant” should only be used in reference to statistics, with p-value included. Please choose a suitable synonym
Avoid overt and nonspecific claims of priority. If your paper is novel, this should come across in your Discussions section quite clearly, and possibly in your statement of the study’s aim
We advise against using claims of novelty in a title; instead, state the basic premise of the research and its importance
Journals prefer the term “reference” whenever mention is made of the influencing, competing, or related literature

Journals prefer specific information about dosage, usually following parameters offered by the journal. We recommend that you describe your dosages in as much non-relative detail as possible following journal parameters
Journals prefer the term “our” when referencing your study, use this rather than any other indicator
Journals prefer specific information about “high resolution MRI,” please include details concerning which aspect of the MRI is “high” resolution and, if necessary, numerical details
Journals prefer the term “attenuation” to the term “density”
The word “correlation” should only be used in reference to statistics. Please choose a suitable synonym
Journals prefer the term “radiograph”/”conventional radiograph” to the term “plain film”
Instead of using the word “case(s),” choose the specific alternative that informs the reader of the exact nature of the “case,” i.e., “patients,” “studies,” etc
Journals prefer the term “intermediate weighted” to the term “proton density”
Please include identical statements of “Purpose” at the beginning and end of the abstract, as per the requirements of [your target journal]
Abstracts should not contain introductory statements. These should all be placed in the “Introduction” section of your manuscript
Purpose statements should not contain unnecessary background information; stick to the central ideas and advances of your study
Add mean age, age range, and number of subjects to your abstract
Your abstract should include your statistical analysis, with p-values included, and, when percentages are given, include both the numerator and denominator
P-values should be given with all numerical data throughout the paper
The study aim needs to be clearly and simply stated
The hypothesis needs to be clearly and simply stated
The outcome needs to be clearly stated
The reference standard needs to be clearly stated here
Mean age and age range should be given separately for your male and female subjects, and for male and female subjects as one group
Include an analysis for statistical significance between the ages of your male and female groups

Describe the inclusion and exclusion criteria you used in determining which patients would be included in your data, and how many patients were excluded in each case. You may wish to create a graphic if you think that the editors/readership would find it useful to have a visual
If the author(s) of the paper also carried out substantial portions of the research, include their initials here, as well as their expertise and years of experience, if relevant
The specific pulse sequence information (e.g. TR, TE, etc.) should be described in the Methods section

Keep your Materials and Methods consistent with Results. For each result, table, and figure in the Results section, ensure that you state within the Materials and Methods a) what was evaluated b) the particulars of the evaluation and c) who performed the evaluation. Likewise, all of the evaluations described in Materials and Methods should have corresponding results in the Results section

Any result stated must have a previous inclusion concerning how these results were found in the Methods section, including information about the time and evaluator(s). We recommend that you add [insert]

To assure consistency between Methods and Results, we recommend that you make a list of all elements discussed in Methods and those discussed in Results, and cross-check them to ensure that each element has a parallel in the other section

In the Methods section, give details of each evaluation performed, including the who did the readings or ratings, their area of expertise and experience, in what way they were blinded, and timing and variability information
Include subheaders for each Methods section
Please describe the role of your tests in the workup of patients
Address in your Methods section whether your subgroups of analysis were pre-specified
Address in your Methods section whether your thresholds were pre-specified or determined based on the data of your tests
You need to include enough information to completely replicate your study
Please make the desired sample population clearer
Please state all inclusion/exclusion criteria in order to make your sampling and analysis methods clear
Were the inclusion/exclusion criteria and thresholds pre-identified or created based on your data?
Please include all possible confounders
The reference standard needs to be clearly stated here
Please state your sample size clearly here
You need to specify your specific method of statistical testing from the outset here
The reference standard needs to be both clear and meaningful
Your cutoff points need to be substantiated based on theoretical distinctions, not just on observation
Make sure to account for all possible confounders
Your cohorts need to be consistent throughout your experiment and paper

Please include all p-values

Please clarify your population

Make sure to state your principle finding clearly and immediately--don't bury the lead!
Editors dislike needless repetition of information in the Discussion that appears elsewhere in the manuscript. Thus, eliminate any redundancy

Discussion sections are both crucial and difficult to write. Here are some tips about the structure of the Discussion we collected from editors at top medical journals: 
 Paragraphs 1-2: state your major finding and its importance 
Paragraph 3: describe what others have previously reported 
Paragraph 4: reveal if your findings were better, confirmatory, or different 
 Paragraph 5: list the limitations of your study 
 (Optional) Paragraph 6: if appropriate, suggest future investigations
You are discussing data here that was not presented in your Results. Please limit discussion to the exact results you presented above
You are presenting new data in Discussion. Any relevant data must be moved to Results
Consensus imaging interpretation in radiologic research may be problematic. Please address this in your limitations paragraph
Share new findings in the framework of the existing research and body of knowledge

For experimental studies, please briefly describe the potential importance of your conclusions as they relate to future practical applications. This information should appear at the end of your "Discussion" section of the manuscript

Avoid mentioning results in the Discussion section not previously shared in the Results section. If you wish to include this data, please describe the evaluation in Materials and Methods and results in Results
Avoid referencing tables or figures in the Discussion section
Editors look for a statement of the study’s limitations at the end of the Discussion section. Please add this information here
Make sure to limit your extrapolations and generalizations to your study population
Please provide a supporting reference for this statement

Please remove any statements of "no difference": either there is a significant observed difference or you failed to find a difference. The latter does not mean that no difference exists, only that you failed to find one with the current population
Since you are stating that you failed to find a difference, please include a discussion of the possibility that this may be due to low power or overly large effect size
Please include a concise and clear statement of the future research that your results indicate could be useful or illuminating
When numbering figures, assign numbers in the order in which they appear in the text
Label all features in a figure named in the captions
[Your target journal] permits up of [#] figures. (However, additional figures may appear online.) You currently have [#] figures. Review and select which remain essential
The head of the arrow should not be an equilateral triangle, as this confuses readers. Instead, use an arrow with a tail or other indicator of directionality
For figures displaying patient images, include the plane of view of each image in the caption (coronal, transverse/axial, longitudinal/sagittal)
Submit each figure as an individual file rather than including multiple in one file

Digital images for accepted manuscripts should be supplied as TIFF files. EPS files are also acceptable. Minimum resolution is 300 dpi with 3 inches (7.62 cm) as the shortest diameter. 7 inches (17.78 cm) should be the longest diameter. Line art images should be submitted as 600 dpi TIFFs or in the program in which they were created
Include the pulse sequence information for any MR images in the caption if they are not stated in Methods
Please state the acquisition modality of each image

Create a separate page, apart from the text, for the figure captions or legends
Please identify the important aspect of the histologic images in the figure caption and annotate the images accordingly
Please make certain that for ALL histologic sections you provide the stain used and the magnification
The small size of this graphic or image renders it difficult to read. Consider enlarging it
Editors like when authors include at least one or two scan images related to the study’s main points
There should be one patient per figure. Each patient’s images should have a different figure
Include the patient’s age and gender in the caption
